critique: This executive order temporarily suspends the eight-hour workday law for laborers and mechanics employed by the Departments of the Army and Air Force. It is motivated by the need to expedite public work activities essential to military support, construction, and international commitments. The order ensures overtime pay for work exceeding eight hours a day. There is no ideological tilt. The order does not address immigration. The order expands executive power by suspending a law. The order does not directly impact federalism. The order prioritizes national security by expediting military-related projects. The order involves economic regulation by mandating overtime pay. The order does not address social inclusion.
